newsitem.title: JORDAN: Israel, Jordan try to put aside Jerusalem row.
newsitem.headline: Israel, Jordan try to put aside Jerusalem row.

text.p: Jordan's King Hussein and Israeli Prime Minster Benjamin Netanyahu tried on Sunday to brush aside a row over Jewish construction plans around Arab East Jerusalem and breathe new life into their three-year peace accord.
Putting on a public show of good neighbourliness after more than three hours of talks, the two leaders warned against escalation of tension in the region.
"We have our views. The Israelis have their views. But we would like to have an atmosphere of calm and understanding," King Hussein told a news conference. "We need to have a good atmosphere."

Netanyahu, making his first trip to an Arab state since Israel signed a long-delayed deal for limited Palestinian self-rule in the West Bank town of Hebron in January, sought to gloss over the Jerusalem issue, which Jordanian officials described earlier on Sunday as "very dangerous".

"We spent quite a lot of time working out how to make the peace between Jordan and Israel come alive in terms of the prospects and opportunities for ordinary Jordanians and Israelis," he said. "This could be a model for the kind of peace we would wish to see throughout the Middle East."

Most Jordanians remain disillusioned over their 1994 peace accord after the promises of rapid economic dividends failed to materialise. A number of ambitious joint projects, including gas supplies and an airport near the Red Sea, have since been shelved or run into difficulties.

King Hussein's warm relations with Netanyahu cooled noticeably after the Israeli Prime Minister approved the opening of a tunnel in Arab East Jerusalem last September, sparking widespread violence in the West Bank. The tunnel was also next to Moslem holy sites.
Jordan's peace treaty with Israel specified that Jordan, which ruled the West Bank until the 1967 Middle East War, would retain custodial duties over Jerusalem's Moslem holy sites.
The king, saying Sunday's talks had been "cordial and frank", reiterated his opposition "to any change (in Jerusalem) which affects or threatens the peace process in any way."
Israel says the whole of Jerusalem is its indivisable capital, while Palestinians say the East Jerusalem will form the capital of a future state.
Jordanian officials said earlier on Sunday the talks were overshadowed by Jordan's concerns over the Israeli plans to build 6,500 new homes for Jews in East Jerusalem.
"We consider them as very dangerous, a threat not just to the Palestinian negotiations but the peace process as a whole," one official said.
Netanyahu, facing an investigation back home about alleged government corruption, warned his domestic political opponents against preparing for his early demise.

"I have one suggestion for them: Wait patiently. You have four good years in the opposition," Netanyahu said. "I intend that you will enjoy another four years in the opposition after that...I'm going to continue to lead Israel in my way, to lead to peace, security, and economic prosperity."
